First and foremost, mathematics is interesting all by itself. Check out some YouTube videos from Numberphile and VSauce. I think those will give you interesting things to think about. The importance of maths: Everything you use came about because we have maths. Phones, computers, cars, etc. But honestly, that’s the boring stuff. Being reasonably skilled in mathematics opens up a lot of interesting things. Engineers, physicists, chemists, biologists: They all have one thing in common. They’re reasonably good at math (at least computations). I think the most important thing about math though, is that it teaches you discipline and critical thinking skills. There are multiple studies that suggest that practicing math makes you “smarter”, because it sharpens your mind and helps you be more analytic. To develop the skills, simply do it. Start with numbers. Add, subtract, divide, multiply. Do them in your head, too! Once you’ve mastered arithmetic (make sure you read a little about set theory too), you can learn about Geometry and Algebra. Once you’ve mastered these things, you can learn Calculus. Calculus is about as far as the careers above I mentioned will go (There is some linear algebra dabbled in as well). You can certainly go well beyond Calculus, as everything up to this point is largely computational mathematics. To get to the good stuff, you’ve got to go farther. Beyond Calculus lies things like abstract algebra, real analysis, number theory, set theory, complex analysis, combinatorics, graph theory, algebraic geometry, applied mathematics, etc. The list goes on for quite a while, but gets a little less broad the farther you venture into more specialized areas. Think of mathematics like a spiral of knowledge. The really good stuff is on the inside, but to get there, you’ve got to ride the spiral down to the center. On your way down, you’ll learn all the basics. The more you ask “Why” and find answers to those questions, the more you’ll learn and love mathematics. It’s really quite beautiful.

I would want to know why you didn’t like math. Maybe you’ve had teachers that taught you math by rote. Maybe you don’t like it because you feel like you’re not very good at it. Maybe you don’t see the point of understanding it. Maybe you come from a species of super intelligent beings and our Earth math is just too low level for you, causing boredom. Each of these differences would require a different type of answer. I would want to know what level of math you were in. Are you a geometry student who is doing proofs for the first time and they’re giving you trouble because you don’t like thinking the problems through? An algebra student who is not doing well with factoring polynomials? I would want to know what you think math is. Whether you see it as a collection of formulas or if you are starting to grasp that math is the language we can understand the universe with? I would want to know if you understood that we could use math to accurately describe something as predictable as the swinging of a pendulum or the path of a projectile, or as complicated as the shape of a flower or the rocks at the Giant’s Causeway? There are a lot of reasons people don’t like math. Sometimes people don’t see the point of it, sometimes people don’t get how to do it, sometimes people don’t know how weird the world outside their window is and don’t know they can explore that weirdness. People tend to turn off those educational inputs that challenge them or make them feel small, they also tend to turn off to those inputs that are presented to them badly. Try to figure out what it is about math that you don’t like. It’s such a broad field, it’s in just about everything. Math is the language the universe speaks in. I would encourage you to get curious about it. There’s a lot of universe out there, surely there’s one corner of it you want to grasp better.

You cannot force yourself to love anything. It comes only when it comes. If you want to understand the love of math, it must come from the need to question certain things. For one, someone who loves math must hate mathematics instruction, always wanting to know why people are telling us that certain things work. A passionate mathematician starts their math instruction questioning everything they are taught, because “It’s not enough to just be told all of this.” Any answer along the lines of, “It just is!” from a teacher should anger the student and put the student into a rage of proofs and analysis until he can come back with rational arguments for every question the student may have. Yes, you may be young and not have learned all of the prerequisites to fully understand why addition is commutative, but if you really want to be passionate about math, these are the exact questions that should keep you up at night.  Being a passionate mathematician is all about questioning authority. It’s not the kind of anti-authoritarianism that most people talk about, being obstinate just for the sake of being obstinate, but instead being investigative, just for the sake of being investigative. In this regard, it’s understandable why there were so many mathematicians that have been philosophers for so much of history. For me, it was finally asking the question: “why are any two things equal?” that led me to Type Theory, which I use all the time in programming. Hint: the answer is “because we say so”, but I leave it to the reader to understand why this is both absolutely correct, and also exactly the phrase that should drive you nuts at the same time!  Finally, you need to understand that what you are learning in school is not math, it’s computation. This makes it so difficult to love math. This is exactly because there are 3 types of people learning mathematics in school: mathematicians, those who will use it to compute, and those who are doing it for mathematical literacy only. People have different interests in the world, and a spectrum of enjoyment with regards to mathematics also varies between individuals. However, I’d like to suggest that it’s possible you will be one of those people precisely because you are asking this question. It’s the realization that you are not motivated, but you are motivated to be motivated, and that can lead to the actual motivation you are after.

The first time I was more seriously exposed to Math was in middle school with Euclidian geometry. We started off with a set of simple axioms that seemed very obvious and built up to statements that were far from obvious. Our professor was patient, kind and inspired in us a sense that we were in some way pursuing truth. At the beginning the truths were not so impressive or profound looking since they could be easily inferred from the axioms. But later on, our professor challenged us with problems that you really had to put some thought in, approach things differently, and see the problem in a novel way. I finally found what creativity meant in mathematics. Creativity for me means to see something in a novel way, beyond simply applying some pre-assigned rules. It’s sort of a jump in thought, where the thought process is no longer linear but experiences a discontinuity. In any pursuit you can be more or less constrained. To convey an artistic, scientific, mathematical message, or life advice, or any kind of information, you are constrained. Mostly you are constrained by reality, which takes the form of physical laws or common sense principles. Take a piece of writing that should offer a piece of advice (like plenty here on Quora). Can the anwers to a question be multiple? Sure, but as long as the reader wants to take into account the social realities in which we live in, offer a reasonable opinion and be genuinely helpful, there are certain hard constraints that go into the writing. But each time, a Quora response can offer the same line of reasoning as many answers before, yet have something unique and novel about it. Every work of quality has certain constraints associated with it. Art is at one end of spectrum, with arguably very few constraints, but even then to make a work of art that can connect to as many people, one is confronted with - yes, you guessed it- constraints. Within a certain branch of thought there’s really something like a ratio of how many constraints there are versus how free you are to do something novel. In Euclidian geometry, you can start with 5 logical statements which give you the constraints, namely any false statement will actually contradict one of your axioms. The fact that you can construct such a beautiful edifice starting from the 5 axioms is testimony to the beauty of Math. If you want to learn Math, the real Math not the one taught in American schools, you could start with Euclidian geometry like I did or with Analysis. Once you understand how to be creative within the constraints of Mathematics, you will stop hating it, and it will leave a mark on you, just like it did on me.

Mathematics is one of the tough subjects for students who fear it the most.None the less i will suggest you some tips which will help you develop interest in Mathematics. 10 Tips to make math an interesting subject: 1.Practice, Practice & More Practice: It is impossible to study maths properly by just reading and listening. To study maths you have to solve some problems. The more you practice answering math problems, the better you get. 2. Review Errors: When you’re practicing with these problems, it’s important to work through the process for each solution. If you have made any mistakes, you should review them and understand where your problem-solving skills let you down. 3. Master the Key Concepts: Do not try to memorize the processes. This is counter-productive. It is much better and rewarding in the long-run to focus on understanding the process and logic that is involved. This will help you understand how you should approach such problems in the future. 4. Understand your Doubts: Sometimes you can get stuck trying to solve part of a maths problem and find it difficult to move on to the next stage. It’s common for many students to skip this question and continue on to the next. You should avoid doing this and instead spend time trying to understand the process of solving the problem. 5. Create a Distraction Free Study Environment: Mathematics is a subject that requires more concentration than any other. A proper study environment and a distraction free area could be the determining factor when solving complex equations or problems in geometry, algebra or trigonometry! 6. Create a Mathematical Dictionary: Mathematics has specific terminology with a lot of vocabulary. We suggest you create Notes or Flashcards with all the concepts, terminology and definitions you need to know. You should include their meanings, some key points and even some sample answers so you can consult them at any time and recap. 7. Apply Maths to Real World Problems: As much as possible, try to apply real-world problems when approaching maths. Maths can be very abstract sometimes so looking for a practical application can help change your perspective and assimilate ideas differently. 8. Review Old Tests and Classroom Examples: The work you do in class, for homework, and on quizzes can offer clues to what your midterm or final exam will look like. Use your old tests and class work to create a personal study guide for your upcoming exam. Look at the way your teacher frames questions – this is probably how they will appear on your test. 9. Use Study Guides For Extra Practice: Use study guides for standardized exams, such as the ACT, SAT, or DSST, to brush up on old material. Study guides usually come equipped with thorough explanations of how to solve a sample problem, and you can often find free ones online. 10. Learn to Work By the Clock: This is a popular study tip for people taking timed exams; especially standardized tests. If you only have 40 minutes for a 100-point test, then you can optimally spend 4 minutes on each 10-point question. Get information about how long the test will be and which types of questions will be on it. Then plan to attack the easier questions first, leaving yourself enough time to spend on the more challenging ones. There are many ways to learn to love math, some of which are based on the perspective of each individual. There are also some tips to keep in mind if you want to experience a personal yearning and love for the subject. These tips are ideas that I've used to help myself enjoy math more, even though I've always enjoyed it to start with (maybe because my father is a retired math teacher with 30+ years of experience :P). • Understand it. To be able to truly appreciate math for what it's worth, you'll want to learn the basic principles of how it works, and where it can be applied both theoretically and in the real world. An enthusiastic and intelligent math teacher can make a big difference for this one! • Look for the countless mathematical patterns that can be found everywhere you go, and in everything you do. These patterns are always there, but if you don't make an effort to observe them, they won't be automatically apparent to you. The most obvious embodiment of math in our surrounding environment is through shapes and their patterns. These patterns can become especially fascinating when you think about concepts that are hard to grasp. For example, say that you want to get from point A to point B. You travel half the distance. Then you travel half the distance from that point (1/4 of the total distance). Then you travel halfway again (1/8 of the total distance), and again, and again, etc. In theory, you could go on infinitely like that and never get to your destination. Simililarly, this can be visualized by the corner of a triangle, which also goes on infinitely. • Make your own mathematical theories. You don't have to be Einstein to think up your own crazy concepts, even if you think they aren't valid. Sometimes, just thinking about the possibilities math offers can get the neurons in your brain firing, and you'll soon be awestruck at how simple and fun math can be. • Don't think of it as work. Our education system has a habit of assigning students a lot of homework. This can lead to resentment toward any given subject, and it even caused me to think I might dislike math while I was in high school. Learning should be fun, but it's hard to make homework look fun, especially when you don't understand it. Mistakes are an important part of learning, and if you are able to go at your own pace, it can be a lot more interesting and a lot less grueling. Think of it as a fun experiment, like a hands-on lab in science class. • Talk to math majors. Once you start up a math conversation with a math major, there's no stopping! They'll go on forever... And the result will probably an increased interest in all areas of math. They will say things you never thought of, and that will cause you to think about all the possibilities and all the theories out there. • Watch YouTube videos about theoretical math. There are tons of videos out there that will amaze you! VSauce is one of my favorites, he makes math (and science) very very lovable. This tip is probably the easiest one :) Hopefully these tips will help you learn to love math! It really is amazing, because it describes how our world works and how WE work. The possibilities with math are endless and there are less rules than you think!

I think it’s intuitive for teacher. We all know this: We are supposed to connect our content to students’ interests. I was a high school math teacher. Niggling in the back of my mind was how to really hook students into learning the content I was teaching with what they were interested in. It regularly stumped me. Truth is, I never had a student come to class and ask me if today was slope day. You know… “Dr. Smith! Is today the day we learn slope? ‘Cause I’ve been waiting and waiting and I am so excited to learn the slope formula…” Never happened. So just how do we connect math content with students’ interests? I want to suggest three general methods (there are more) with a few examples at different grade levels (Smith b&c, 2017). Connect students’ hobbies and passions to concepts rather than skills.Sometimes thinking of a hobby that relates to a specific skill can trip us up, but thinking about bigger concepts in which the skill embeds can link to hobbies. For example: Addition and subtraction, which is really about joining and separating in elementary grades, naturally links to collecting things, which most elementary students do.Unit rates in middle school naturally connect with bargain shopping… and what middle school student doesn’t want to buy something?Polyhedra in high school Geometry can be studied through art and architecture – especially sculptors, famous skylines, and monuments.These connections can be used to show the usefulness of the skills to be taught, or be the basis for word problems (make them personal and chatty when writing rather than text book-like) or a larger PBL or other assessment project. There was a research study that showed that changing the context of a word problem to something students were interested in (rather than the typical word problems often used), such as shopping, computers, music or cell phones resulted in students learning better, faster, and remembering it four units later! The numbers were not changed from the original problem, only the context. (Walkington, et. al, 2014). These connections can be used to introduce a unit as a teaser, as context problems to intrigue students throughout a unit, or as a formative or summative assessment. Use novelty for a change of pace.Brain research has let us know that we can hook students into content through connections (see point 1), appropriate challenge, and novelty (Sousa, 2015). Perhaps one of the greatest detriments in interesting students with mathematics is the sheer predictability of what will happen in class. Sometimes the thought of changing how we run class can be intimidating or overwhelming. What if it doesn’t work or go well? What if I can’t manage the class? Truthfully, it might not be perfect and it will definitely be messy. It’s still worth it! Doing something out of the ordinary might be as simple as changing the order of your class routine. For example, in a mathematics workshop (and most constructivist math lessons) students begin with exploring a hands-on task that they have not yet been taught in order to start forming their own connections. These explorations could be: Rolling dice with a partner to make two-digit numbers, and then putting them in ascending order prior to formalizing the roll of place value in primary grades. Numbers can be ordered based on a hundreds chart if students can’t count that high.Sorting shapes and creating categories for their groupings prior to learning names, characteristics and the hierarchy of polygons for intermediate students.Using two-color counters in various arrangements to wipe out “zero pairs” in order for middle school students to discover the patterns for adding integers. This would be done rather than teaching the “rules” for adding integers. Students might need to be told in advance what is a zero pair.Use a Concept Attainment model (These are functions vs. These are not functions) with high school students to have them determine what is and is not a function. Examples (both of and of not) would include graphs, tables, and equations to start, and may extend into context descriptions.Other ideas for novelty include dice rolling to generate problems, bringing in a large deck of cards to draw for partners or groups or even for typical probability problems – the size (very large or very small) of items adds novelty. Use video. The list is endless of ways to bring in a fresh approach and just do something a little different. Offer choice.Offering choice to students in how they will learn, practice, or demonstrate learning is by far the most common way we tap the interest of our students. In fact, research suggests that offering choice a minimum of 35% of the time in class will increase students’ intrinsic motivation (Jensen, 1998). When designing choices for students, bear these principles in mind (Smith a, 2017): Be sure that every choice stays true to the learning goal of the lesson. It is possible to design a variety of activities that accomplish different goals without even realizing that has happened.Be sure that everyone has to address the essential understanding and conceptual basis of the topic regardless of the specific task.Take extra care that each option has the same rigor and effort requirements. If students choose a task because it appears easier than others, it should be because the structure of the task fits a comfortable way for them to learn rather than it actually being easier.Be aware of how long each option should take students to complete. My question to you would be: What is the definition of “very interesting” in your case? Mathematics is the science of thinking. Mathematics is a game. You are given pieces of information, a goal and the rules of game: that is the image of a unproven theorem in my mind. When it comes to solution of problems is nearly the same, because any problem is a very small bit of a theorem. Mathematics, therefore, makes you reason not only in an analytical but in a synthetical way. Then is some kind of training for the mind. Because of this, mathematics are not only numbers. Number theory, arithmetics and numerical calculations are only a tiny bit of the deal. Mathematics is also generalisation: what happens if you weaken your assumptions. Mathematics is also creativity: if you see that two apparently different mathematical objects share some formal behaviour, you ask if there is some connection and you create links between theories. Mathematics then gives you an advantage in the real world, not because you can calculate something, but because you can detect better misleading ideas, errors and fallacies. And you can avoid them better in your own reasoning. Isn’t that very interesting?
